Summaries of the impacts on community groups from project activity: Community group Rio Bravo, Suchitepéquez (Palmeras) – Impact: increased employment opportunities, increased perception/recognition of the value of forest resources, miscellaneous donations for community infrastructure improvements; type of benefit/cost/risk: actual/direct/benefit; CCB v3.0, VCS v4.4; CCB & VCS monitoring report template; CCB version 3.0, VCS version 4.4; change in well‑being – new and permanent employment with social benefits; more employment opportunities for women (women generally not employed in sugar plantations or cattle production due to labor intensity); education on value of forest resources during stakeholder outreach; community infrastructure improvements. Community group Santa Barbara, Suchitepéquez (Palmeras and Asunción) – Impact: increased employment opportunities, increased perception/recognition of the value of forest resources, miscellaneous donations for community infrastructure improvements, providing critical ecosystem services such as hydrological services and erosion control – project provides potable water to over 1,500 individuals from neighboring communities (Aldea Día de Reyes and Santa Barbara); type of benefit/cost/risk: actual/direct/benefit; change in well‑being – new and permanent employment with social benefits; more employment opportunities for women; education on value of forest resources during stakeholder outreach; community infrastructure improvements; potable water free provided for community of limited resources. Community group Santo Domingo, Suchitepéquez (Los Patos) – Impact: increased employment opportunities, increased perception/recognition of the value of forest resources, miscellaneous donations for community infrastructure improvements; type of benefit/cost/risk: actual/direct/benefit; change in well‑being – new and permanent employment with social benefits; more employment opportunities for women (women generally not employed in sugar plantations or cattle production due to labor intensity); education on value of forest resources during stakeholder outreach; community infrastructure improvements. Community group Patulul, Suchitepéquez (El Horizonte) – Impact: increased employment opportunities, increased perception/recognition of the value of forest resources, miscellaneous donations for community; type of benefit/cost/risk: actual/direct/benefit; change in well‑being – new and permanent employment with social benefits; education on value of forest resources during stakeholder outreach; community infrastructure improvements. Community group Workers – Impact: technical capacity building and improved forest management skills and knowledge; type of benefit/cost/risk: actual/direct/benefit; change in well‑being – improved skills and know‑how with specific training according to activities performed, more education on value of forest resources and best management practices; CCB v3.0, VCS v4.4; CCB & VCS monitoring report template; CCB version 3.0, VCS version 4.4; 4.1.1.1 creating economic opportunities.

According to the initial statement of the project proponent, by securing carbon finance and VCS registration, investors for the project will remain engaged and committed to invest in this innovative project, obtaining the required rate of return (RRR) and moving forward to build a diversified income model for rubber plantations based on rubber, carbon, and wood under the highest environmental, social, and economic standards of sustainable and/or responsible forest management.

Several key strategies are being implemented to generate these benefits: sustainable land management—by adopting sustainable agricultural practices and improving land productivity, the project helps reduce the need for land expansion, thereby conserving biodiversity in surrounding areas.

Additionally, regarding the measures the project will take to maintain and enhance benefits beyond the project lifetime, at the end of the project rubber trees will be harvested for timber and the plantation will be replanted as stated in the Management Plans 36.2.3 Stakeholder Engagement 2.3.1 Community Consultation (G3.8). Stakeholder consultations were carried out in each project instance to give communities information about the project and provide the opportunity for stakeholders to give feedback regarding any impacts of project activities.

Recognizing these farms, through income from carbon credits and commitments acquired by participating in the project, allows workers to have decent wages recognized by law; they also receive additional benefits to the monthly salary (two additional salaries per year); they are paid on time—unlike many neighboring farms that delay wages; they have access to social security; and they have a local job offer, which is advantageous given the distance to work.

Afforestation, reforestation, and revegetation (ARR) activities increase carbon stocks in woody biomass (and in some cases soils) by establishing, increasing, and/or restoring vegetative cover through planting, sowing, and/or human-assisted natural regeneration of woody vegetation (VCS Program Definitions). Category metric achievements during the monitoring period: number of hectares of existing production forest land in which IFM7 practices have occurred as a result of the project’s activities, measured against the without-project scenario; number of hectares of non-forest land in which improved land management has occurred as a result of the project’s activities, measured against the without-project scenario; total number of community members who have improved skills and/or knowledge resulting from training provided as part of project activities; number of female community members who have improved skills and/or knowledge resulting from training provided as part of project activities; >300; 5% total employment; total number of people employed in project activities, expressed as number of full-time employees; number of women employed in project activities, expressed as number of full-time employees; CCB monitoring >300; CCB monitoring 5% total employment; 8 employed in project activities means people directly working on project activities in return for compensation (financial or otherwise), including employees, contracted workers, sub-contracted workers, and community members that are paid to carry out project-related work.
